Posts.Content: Oct 25, 2010 03:14PM mohonda wrote: Wow,, lots of advice here. I think I will go to a pain specialist. I have been on Oxy 3 days now. My first day I felt speedy, like my heart rate was up. I did not have pain and over did it playing goalie soccer with my 8yr old nephew. The 2nd day, very groggy, sleeping in car as passenger. Today not to sleepy. I will continue on the Oxy for a few weeks and see how it goes. I am having poopy issues even though I took miralax and docuclax. I am still waking up at nite so I probably need something to help me sleep. I like the idea of a pain pump. Cat I was hospitalized for 3 weeks upon dx and on morphine, dulated, vicodin. When I left I continued the patch and vicodin. I had very bad bowel problems for several months. I have been on Zometa and it is working according to the last blood test. I already have fractures in spine and don't think it would be a good idea to stop at this point. I will definetly get a specialist. You ladies have been great. Hugs Mo
Posts.Title: Pain meds the good bad and ugly mohonda mohonda

Posts.Content: mohonda wrote: Hi Ladies, I thought of starting a pain thread. I have been taking them over a year for bone mets and it seems like I still could use advise. I thought taking less would be better for my organs ie liver and kidneys. But it turns out if I am not on a consistent pain plan I have more symptoms. I don't know what is normal anymore when it comes to pain. I did not want to take too much because like in the poopy post we have problems in that department. So for a year I have been on a Fentynal patch 75mg every 3 days and vicodin as needed. Well I was only taking 5mg in the am and 5 in the pm trying to be conservative. But at nite I had so much pain. I could not sleep in one position more than a few hours without waking up with pain. I saw a new dr traveling and she is going to change my rx to Ocy because it last 12 hours. I have no idea why my other drs would not prescribe this. Maybe because the pharmacy thinks your a drug addict when you try to fill. They don't even carry it in the CVS they have to mail it to you. Last nite I took 3 5mg vicodin spread out am, afternoon and before bedtime. This is the first time in a year I did not have pain sleeping in a position and having to wake up. When your sick and in pain you forget what is normal and don't realize the pain is too much. Anyone have anything to add? Has anyone switched from vicodin to Oxy? Mo Maureen K Dx 8/23/2009, 1cm, Stage IV, mets, ER+ Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Pain meds the good bad and ugly mohonda mohonda

I don't think tamx ever worked, now on armx but scans in Sept more progression. However, a bone biobsy in Sept on spine mets negative for cancer. Happy for that, but tumor markers keep going up. Nov I will do new tm tests to determine if hormones are working. If still up maybe chemo soon. I think after reading responses here I may want to wait another month before I rush to judgement. Hoping for results for all of us.

Posts.Title: Chemotherapy and eyesight question tania_s jeanne46

Posts.Content: Jun 7, 2010 11:59PM mohonda wrote: I had the same concerns about addiction. I am taking Fetynal 75mg patch and the generic Vicodin 5mg 2X a day plus Aleeve 2tabs 2X a day. But if I miss taking my patch on time or the vicodin I am in pain and we don't know how much time we have so we shouldn't worry about that. I lived in C A until March of this year. While I hadn't smoked pot since HS some 29 yrs ago I decided to try it during chemo because I couldn't eat from the side eff of chemo and rad. I will say it helped tremendously, with my eating and relaxing and pain. But now in FL and technically its not legal for pain here. I also was constipated during the first 6 months taking these drugs but now I am fine in that department from eating lots of greens, fruit and oatmeal. I also think your body adjusts.

Posts.Content: Apr 30, 2010 07:28AM mohonda wrote: Hi, Thank you all for the feedback. I realize from the feedback that each person's cancer is individual and treatment will vary according to size and location of primary. I do believe my Onc did not want to do surgery for several reasons. I was weak after the chemo and I needed to gain back some strength and weight and stabilize my blood counts. Secondly, as mentioned above there is no research to support whether removal of a small tumor is beneficial when it has met to the bones. I think I had a problem with his recommendation because I recently moved from CA and he is my new Onc in FL and he disagreed with my Onc in CA treatment plan to have me on chemo. He stated and showed me a website that was put together by all onocologists in the country with its protocol for treatment plans for various cancers. In it for my stage 4 cancer with met to bones there was no call for chemo. But I think because I was in such pain from met of hip and bone they need to stabilize my condition. I do want to get a 2nd opinion though despite everything. However, the hospital my onc recommended is 2 hrs away and my onc is affiliated with it and probably will recommend the same treatment plan. So to me it makes no sense to get a 2nd opinion there when it would most likely be exactly the same treatment. I will most likely look for another hospital that is not affiliated with my doctor. thanks again and stay strong!

Posts.Content: Jul 28, 2010 11:27AM mohonda wrote: I thought I would update this forum since I went to Mofitt cancer center in Tampa FL> I was suprised to learn that taking out the source of the cancer, tumor in breast can actually exasperate the cancer in the bones or other locations. So, it was not recommended to take the tumor out. It can also serve as a way to measure the cancer to see if it gets bigger or smaller. I am happy to keep my breasts.

Posts.Content: mohonda wrote: Hi, New to the site, I was diagnosed with bone cancer in Aug of 09. It wasn't until Jan 2010 that it was confirmed I had a breast primary. I had 5 rounds of chemo and months of radiation to stop pain in hip and sternum and back. Currently I am at a stand still with treatment and only taking Tamoxofin. I do have a small tumor in my breast and my Oncologist want to wait a few months before a masectomy is done. I asked why and his response was to wait and see if the cancer spreads to organs. I told him I did not understand that if I have a tumor in my breast shouldn't it be removed. It is small but it could spread. Thats my reasoning. I am finally able to do some normal things like walk my dog. But the doctor says this is standard protocol for my diagnosis. Anyone have any feedback on this? Posts.Title: Great PET scan! nancyh olisad

Posts.Content: mohonda wrote: Hi I am looking for anyone has had this procedure for spine fractures or compressions. I am going to go ahead and have this done if insurance approves. I have 5 fractures and more compressions. I will have to do 2 or 3 surgeries because they can only do 4 spine cells at a time. Some benefiets are stablizing the spine to prevent breaks and paralysis. Also, the procedure uses a liquid heated up to 90 degrees which can kill cancer cells on spine. The surgeons insert a needle like device with a baloon attached it opens up the spinal cell and then they insert concrete. YIKES can u imagine. But I am told they have done over 300,000 of them. Thanks for your feedback Maureen K Dx 8/23/2009, 1cm, Stage IV, mets, ER+ Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Kyphoplasty for spine fractures mohonda Lynne

Posts.Content: Aug 19, 2010 05:00PM mohonda wrote: Oh Norma what a bummer after surgery to find out more tumors. I hope there is a way to treat them. I don't understand waiting 6 months for scans Suzanne. I have been on a 3 month schedule. I had kyphoplasty surgery yesterday and was able to go to my hotel afterward. I had done research on their website and talked to the pre-op nurse but no where or no one explained that the dr was going to hammer the instrument into my spine. I opted forÂ the new procedure not using anthesia. I was given something intravenously that made me sleepy but not knock me out. So, I awoke to a hammer banging on my spine with something like a chisel. I was not a happy camper. Anyway I am home now and hope to see the next few days how it will help me. I have several fractures on my spine and lost 4in in height. Not to mention the pain which I hope I will have less of. This procedure should protect my spine from breaking. I need to have 2 more of them. I think I will opt to sleep over and do the anthesia. I don't know if this helps Suzanne, but maybe someone will write on a similiar issue with your femor. Good luck girl and get more frequent scans.

Posts.Title: Kyphoplasty for spine fractures mohonda Lynne

Posts.Content: Aug 22, 2010 11:33PM mohonda wrote: An update on the Kyphoplasty. I had on the 18th not quite a week and I actually walked out of hospital the very same day. I opted for out patient which they do not give anthestia, instead another pain and intravenous medication which doesn't completely knock you out. So, I awoke during surgery when they were hammering the instrument into my back. They never mentioned that either now I know why. It was painful and awful listening to them hammer this thing in my back. It felt forever because they had to do it 4 times for each vertebrae. Its not quite a week yet and I cannot tell if it will help me because I still have pain where the incisions were made. I mistakenly took a bike ride 2 days afterward not a good idea. I was in pain afterwards. I will update again in a week or 2 if there is improvement
